{{No footnotes|date=December 2009}} {{Political anthropology|expanded=Basic concepts}}
'''Achieved status''' is a concept developed by the anthropologist [[Ralph Linton]] denoting a [[social status|social position]] that a person can acquire on the basis of merit; it is a position that is earned or chosen. It is the opposite of [[ascribed status]]. It reflects personal skills, abilities, and efforts. Examples of achieved status are being an Olympic athlete, being a criminal, or being a college professor.
Status is important sociologically because it comes with a set of rights, obligations, behaviors, and duties that people occupying a certain position are expected or encouraged to perform. These expectations are referred to as [[role]]s. For instance, the role of a "professor" includes teaching students, answering their questions, being impartial, appropriately.
==Achieved status vs. ascribed status==
[[Ascribed status]] is a position assigned to individuals or groups based on traits beyond their control, such as sex, race, or parental social status. This is usually associated with "closed" societies. Achieved status is distinguished from [[ascribed status]] by virtue of being earned.
Many positions are a mixture of achievement and ascription; for instance, a person who has achieved the status of being a physician is more likely to have the ascribed status of being born into a wealthy family. This is usually associated with "open" societies or "social" class societies.
==Social mobility==
[[Social mobility]] refers to one's ability to move their status either up or down within the [[social stratification]] system, as compared with their family’s status in early life. Some people with achieved status have improved their position within the social system via their own merit and achievements.
Someone may also have achieved status that decreases their position within the social system, such as by becoming a notorious criminal. In a society that one's position in that society can change due to their actions, either increase or decrease, that society can be referred to as an Open System. A Closed System society would not allow [[Social mobility]] as easily as an Open System.
==Cultural capital== [[Cultural capital]] is a concept, developed by sociologist [[Pierre Bourdieu]], that can refer to both achieved and ascribed characteristics. They are desirable qualities (either material or symbolic) that contribute to one's social status; any advantages a person has which give him/her a higher status in society. It may include high expectations, forms of knowledge, skill, and education, among other things.
Parents provide children with cultural capital, the attitudes and knowledge that make the educational system a comfortable familiar place in which they can succeed easily. There are other types of capital as well; [[Social capital]] refers to ones membership in groups, relationships, and networks. It too can have a significant impact on achievement level.
===Education=== Industrialization has led to a vast increase in the possible standard of living for the average person but also made this increase necessary. For the productivity of the average worker to rise, he or she had to receive far more education and training. This successively made the average worker much less replaceable and therefore more powerful. Hence, it became necessary to satisfy workers’ demands for a larger share.
===Employment=== According to sociologist [[Rodney Stark]], few [[United States|Americans]] believe coming from a wealthy family or having political connections is necessary to get ahead. In contrast, many people in other industrialized nations think these factors are necessary for advancement. Americans are more likely than the people in these nations to rate “hard work” as very important for getting ahead. While most nations value hard work, the [[Italians]], for example, are hardly more likely to rate it as very important than they are to think one needs political connections.
===Income=== People with a lower income will generally be a better example of moving up in the [[social stratification]] and achieving status. This holds to be evident in most cases because those who accrue a lower income usually have the motivation to achieve a greater status through their own ambitions and hard work. Those of higher income are typically the result of achieving status. In other cases the people of higher income may have unjustly acquired that position, or were ascribed the status and income they hold (such as monarchs, family run businesses, etc.).
Those without the privilege of ascribing their status will generally have the greater motivation of achieving their own status. The general economic well being of the society the person lives in also tends to be another factor in their status and to what extent they are able to achieve their status.
For example, [[United States|Americans]] are less likely than people in other industrialized nations to object to current income variances. According to [[Rodney Stark]], in 1992, only twenty-seven percent of Americans strongly agreed that income disparities in their country were too large. In contrast, more than half of [[Russians]], [[Italians]], and [[Bulgarians]] agreed with this statement.
==In stratification systems around the world==
In all societies a person's social status is the result of both ascribed and achieved characteristics. Societies differ markedly on several dimensions in this process: what attributes are used to assign status, the relative importance of ascribed versus achieved attributes, the overall potential for social mobility, the rates of mobility that actually occurred, and the barriers for particular sub-groups to enjoy upward mobility in that society.
==Cultural differences around the world==
===Medieval Europe=== One's status in [[medieval Europe]] was primarily based on ascription. People born into the noble class were likely to keep a high position and people born of peasants were likely to stay in a low position. This political system is known as [[feudalism]] and does not allow for much [[social mobility]].
===Feudalism in Latin America=== Bolivia has had past newspaper advertisements that claimed to have land, animals and [[peasants]] for sale. The peasants weren't necessarily slaves but placed in their [[social class]] and obligated to work due to their bind to the land they lived and farmed. This sort of social interaction is based mainly on the people's strong belief of tradition and to uphold the actions of the past. In 1971 [[Ernesto Laclau]] addressed the argument of whether Latin America was either under a social system of [[feudalism]] or [[capitalism]]. He determined that the social system was extremely different from the capitalistic system in [[Europe]] and America, so therefore Latin America would be more closely related to have a Feudalism approach to social interaction.
===Caste system=== {{main|Caste}} The formation of hierarchy differs somewhere between the polarities of given and achieved status.<ref>Japan's Invisible Race: Caste in Culture and Personality, p.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=T0_EWolOfpUC&pg=PA334&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false334], George A. De Vos, Hiroshi Wagatsuma</ref> In [[caste]] systems, ascription is the overpowering basis for status. Traditional society in South Asia and other parts of the world such as Egypt, India, Japan, and others were composed of castes. Each group was limited to certain occupations. Low paying occupations such as collecting garbage, were reserved for one caste, whose members were excluded from holding any other occupation. Correspondingly, highly skilled occupations, such as being a priest, [[goldsmith]], were reserved for another caste. However, some people managed through talent and luck to rise above their given caste. For example, great aptitude as a soldier was often a way to reach a higher status.

promotes the protection of [[Afrikaner culture]],<ref name=thlaff>{{cite web|title=AfriForum and the rise of the new right|url=http://www.thoughtleader.co.za/thornegodinho/2014/01/08/afriforum-and-the-rise-of-the-new-right/|publisher=Thought Leader|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> and has opposed [[Renaming in South Africa|renaming streets]] and [[affirmative action]]. AfriForum has attracted significant controversy because of its views, particularly about [[Apartheid]].<ref name="ajLobbyingUnderFire">{{cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/05/south-african-group-fire-lobbying-white-rights-180514054424008.html|title=South African group under fire for lobbying US for white rights|website=www.aljazeera.com}}</ref><ref name="timesLiveWhoIsKriel"/><ref name="timesLiveUproarApartheid"/><ref name="iolDenyBrutality">{{cite web|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/opinion/no-one-can-and-should-deny-the-brutality-of-apartheid-15052389|title=No-one can and should deny the brutality of apartheid|publisher=IOL News}}</ref>
According to AfriForum CEO, [[:af:Kallie Kriel|Kallie Kriel]], AfriForum is a [[Civil and political rights|civil rights]] initiative to mobilise civil society and specifically minority communities, in order to take part in democratic debate. Kriel further stated that AfriForum would like to achieve balance in South Africa. “True democracy needs alternative voices in order to succeed. While we aren’t a political party, we give alternative ideas and suggestions, where applicable, to the government stance.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thoughtleader.co.za/traps/2008/04/16/afrikaner-aspirations-%E2%80%93-an-hour-with-afriforums-kallie-kriel/|title=Afrikaner aspirations: An hour with AfriForum’s Kallie Kriel|work=thoughtleader.co.za}}</ref> AfriForum's claim to be a civil rights organisation has been questioned in the South African media,<ref name="news24SisuluExaggerate">{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/dont-exaggerate-sisulu-asks-afriforum-20180515|title=Don't exaggerate, Sisulu asks AfriForum|publisher=News24}}</ref><ref name="citizenIronyArgument">{{cite web|url=https://citizen.co.za/opinion/opinion-columns/1928535/afriforum-cant-spot-the-irony-in-its-own-whiny-argument/|title=AfriForum can’t spot the irony in its CEO|publisher=Sowetan}}</ref><ref name="sundaytimesHogarth">{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/sunday-times/opinion-and-analysis/2018-05-19-mampara-of-the-week-kallie-kriel/|title=Mampara of rights|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-45336840|title=The groups playing on the fears of a 'white African farmers, explained|work=Vox|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/south-africa-afriforum-trump-kiss-death-180828131030337.html|title=South Africa's Afriforum and Trump's kiss of death|last=Msimang|first=Sisonke|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref>
The movement's [[youth wing]] is called ''AfriForum Youth''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afriforumyouth.co.za/who-are-we/beleid/|title=Home - AfriForum Jeug|work=AfriForum Jeug}}</ref><ref name="mgHETNslams">{{cite web|url=https://mg.co.za/article/2013-09-30-hten-slams-afriforums-student-race-request|title=HETN slams AfriForum's student race request|first=Bongani|last=Nkosi|publisher=Mail and Guardian}}</ref>
==History== AfriForum was founded in 2006. AfriForum's Civil Rights Charter was officially adopted by the organization on 7 September 2006 during a discussion forum held in Pretoria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afriforum.co.za/about/project-100-000|title=AfriForum|work=AfriForum}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=May 2018}} Its leader, Kallie Kriel, was previously a member of the [[Conservative Party (South Africa)|Conservative Party]], and a leader of the [[Freedom Front Plus]] (FF+) youth wing, and a large number of its executive leadership were formerly associated with Freedom Front Plus.<ref name="thlaff"/>
The organisation recruited its 100 000th member in July 2014 and its 200 000th member in November 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.afriforum.co.za/afriforum-enters-new-phase-200-000-active-members/|title=AfriForum enters new phase with 200 000 active members - AfriForum|date=2017-11-01|work=AfriForum|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=May 2018}}
==Campaigns and policies== [[File:AfriForum - Standerton-betoging.jpg|thumb|left|AfriForum protest outside the [[Pretoria High Court]]]] The organisation's principal focus is inter alia on the following areas: civil, safety and security, community affairs, local government, environmental affairs, education as well as preserving the language, culture and heritage in South Africa.{{fact|date=May 2018}}
In 2009, the group contested the presence of [[Robert Mugabe]] at the inauguration of [[Jacob Zuma]]'s presidency.<ref name=gsd>{{cite web|title=Great song and dance as Zuma is sworn in as president of South Africa|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/may/07/south-africa-zuma-president-inauguration|publisher=theguardian.com|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> It was also involved in a bid to prevent the delivery of [[Alouette III]] Air Force helicopters to the [[Zimbabwe Army|Zimbabwean army]].<ref name=zimheli>{{cite web|title=AfriForum wins bid to halt Zim helicopter delivery|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2013-01-26-afriforum-wins-bid-to-halt-zim-helicopter-delivery|publisher=Mail & Guardian|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref>
AfriForum has opposed [[fracking]] in the [[Karoo]]<ref name="tkag">{{cite web|title=TKAG, Afriforum become anti-fracking force |url=http://www.thenewage.co.za/73896-1021-53-TKAG_Afriforum_become_antifracking_force |publisher=The New Age Online |accessdate=14 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116072223/http://www.thenewage.co.za/73896-1021-53-TKAG_Afriforum_become_antifracking_force |archivedate=16 January 2014 }}</ref> as well as poaching<ref name="iol.co.za">{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/crime-courts/fury-as-poaching-charges-dropped-1.1270893|title=Fury as poaching charges dropped|author=Independent Newspapers Online|work=Independent Online}}</ref> It has also campaigned against [[e-toll (South Africa)|electronic road tolling in Gauteng]].<ref name=etollsnao>{{cite web|title=E-toll notification unlawful: AfriForum |url=http://www.thenewage.co.za/Detail.aspx?news_id=71296&cat_id=1099 |publisher=The New Age Online |accessdate=14 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116072520/http://www.thenewage.co.za/Detail.aspx?news_id=71296&cat_id=1099 |archivedate=16 January 2014 }}</ref>
AfriForum has been a vocal critic of the [[ANC]]'s response to the [[South African farm attacks|farm attack]] cases, claiming that the party bears a responsibility for "remain[ing] silent" about the violence,<ref name=blamfm>{{cite web|title=AfriForum blames ANC for farm murders|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2012/09/12/afriforum-blames-anc-for-farm-murders|publisher=Times LIVE|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> and lodging a complaint to the [[South African Human Rights Commission]] against the [[Department of Police (South Africa)|Police Minister]] for failing to do enough to protect farmers.<ref name=farmiol>{{cite web|title=Afriforum takes farm murders to SAHRC|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/crime-courts/afriforum-takes-farm-murders-to-sahrc-1.1524798|publisher=IOL.co.za|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref>
AfriForum launched the book ''Kill the Boer''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.killtheboerbook.com/reviews/|title=Reviews - Kill the Boer Book|work=Kill the Boer Book|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref> written by [[Ernst Roets]], Deputy CEO of AfriForum, on 28 June 2018.<ref name="Hlatshaneni">{{cite news |last1=Hlatshaneni |first1=Simnikiwe |title=Outrage surrounds book claiming top ANC officials ‘killed the boer’ |url=https://citizen.co.za/news/south-africa/1964479/outrage-surrounds-book-claiming-top-anc-officials-killed-the-boer/ |accessdate=24 November 2018 |publisher=The Citizen |date=27 June 2018}}</ref>
===Crime and corruption=== The organisation has often criticised government for its lack of willingness to address the problem of farm murders. AfriForum is of the opinion that farm murders should be declared a priority crime, and has raised widespread local awareness and increasing international awareness of the problem by means of several campaigns, including the ‘Stop the Murders’ campaign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politicsweb.co.za/politicsweb/view/politicsweb/en/page71654?oid=310483&sn=Detail&pid=71654|title=Make farm murders a priority crime (like rhino poaching) - AfriForum - PARTY - Politicsweb|work=politicsweb.co.za}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=May 2018}} The organisation has also campaigned to address the overall problem of crime and corruption, especially with regard to municipal employees guilty of fraud.{{fact|date=May 2018}}
====Private prosecutions==== {{see|Gerrie Nel}} The organisation formed a [[private prosecution]]s unit, headed by well-known former state prosecutor [[Gerrie Nel]], amid allegations that the [[National Prosecuting Authority]] (NPA) was selective in prosecutions, and politically biased.<ref name="conversationHowPrivateProsecutionsWillWork">{{Cite news|url=https://theconversation.com/explainer-how-south-africas-first-private-prosecutions-unit-will-work-72389|title=Explainer: how South Africa's first private prosecutions unit will work|last=Feldhaus|first=Chantelle|work=The Conversation|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en}}</ref> In 2017, Nel undertook to assist the victim of an alleged assault by [[Grace Mugabe]], wife of [[Robert Mugabe]].<ref>https://www.thesouthafrican.com/gerrie-nel-takes-on-grace-mugabe-will-assist-alleged-assault-victim/</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nehandaradio.com/2017/08/17/gerrie-nel-sets-sights-grace-mugabe/|title=Gerrie Nel sets sights on Grace Mugabe – Nehanda Radio|date=2017-08-17|work=Nehanda Radio|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>https://www.thesouthafrican.com/as-gerrie-nel-targets-grace-mugabe-we-remember-the-bulldogs-biggest-cases/</ref>
In 2018, AfriForum undertook a private prosecution of EFF leader Julius Malema on charges of fraud and corruption, after the NPA failed to continue prosecuting the case.<ref name="iolMalemaAfriForumExplainsCase"/> AfriForum had initially laid the charges against Malema in 2011.<ref name="iolMalemaAfriForumExplainsCase"> {{cite web|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/why-prosecute-malema-afriforum-explains-its-case-14536130|title=Why prosecute Malema? AfriForum explains its case - IOL News|publisher=}}</ref>
AfriForum committed to undertake a private prosecution of Duduzane Zuma, son of then-President [[Jacob Zuma]], for [[culpable homicide]], after a vehicle driven by Duduzane Zuma was involved in a 2014 motor vehicle crash that killed two black female [[minibus taxi]] commuters, and the National Prosecuting Authority declined to prosecute, despite an inquest finding that the crash was caused by Zuma's negligence.<ref name="ewnBLfConfrontKriel">http://ewn.co.za/2018/07/12/blf-confront-afriforum-s-kriel-after-duduzane-zuma-court-appearance</ref> Following AfriForum's move to privately prosecute Zuma, the National Prosecuting Authority decided to pursue a prosecution instead.<ref name="ewnStrongCaseZuma">http://ewn.co.za/2018/07/12/gerrie-nel-afriforum-has-strong-case-against-duduzane-zuma</ref>
The organisation undertook a prosecution of the chairperson of the [[National Council of Provinces]], [[Thandi Modise]], after allegations of [[animal cruelty]] at her [[North West (South Africa)|North West]] farm, where, in 2014, the [[NSPCA]] found "scores" of animals starving to death from apparent neglect, and the NPA failed to prosecute her.<ref name="encaScoresModise">http://www.enca.com/scores-dead-animals-found-thandi-modises-farm</ref><ref name="news24ToProsecuteModise">https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/afriforum-to-privately-prosecute-thandi-modise-20180719</ref><ref name="ewnTakeOnCruelty">http://ewn.co.za/2018/07/19/afriforum-to-take-on-thandi-modise-for-animal-cruelty</ref>
===Education, language and culture=== Two of the core objectives of AfriForum Youth have been the promotion of multilingualism<ref name=tra>{{cite web|last1=Trapido |first1=Michael |title=No country for Afrikaans then? |url=http://www.thoughtleader.co.za/traps/2008/07/16/petty-apartheid-revisited/|website=thoughtleader.co.za |publisher=Mail&Guardian |date = July 16, 2008 |accessdate=1 December 2014}}</ref> and mother tongue education in South Africa, and for youth in the country to be exempted from [[affirmative action]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afriforumyouth.co.za/?page_id=13|title=Home - AfriForum Jeug|work=AfriForum Jeug}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=May 2018}}
AfriForum has strongly opposed the proposed renaming of South Africa's capital from [[Pretoria]] to Tshwane, as well as street renaming in Pretoria.<ref>SABC News, AfriForum takes Pretoria street name-changes to court, 13 December 2012.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/81-against-Pretoria-name-change-20130414|title=81% against Pretoria name change|work=News24}}</ref>
A campaign against racial quotas in higher education saw AfriForum Youth members paint themselves black to protest the alleged discrimination against 30 learners who were turned away from the [[University of Pretoria]].<ref name=dmblp>{{cite web|title=Analysis: AfriForum Youth's absurd black paint protest|url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2012-01-30-analysis-afriforum-youths-absurd-black-paint-protest/#.UtVCefYfvMg|publisher=Daily Maverick|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> Another campaign protesting racial quotas involved charging students of different races different prices for a cup of coffee, with white students paying R5 a cup, coloured and Indians R3, and blacks R1.<ref name=affcoffee>{{cite web|title=Afriforum Youth to offer blacks cheaper coffee|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2013/04/25/afriforum-youth-to-offer-blacks-cheaper-coffee|publisher=Times LIVE|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref>
In 2014 AfriForum attempted to suppress a report into a [[Nazism|Nazi]]-style initiation ceremony at the Potchefstroom Campus of [[North-West University]], claiming that the report discriminated against Afrikaners.<ref name="2014CityPressNaziReport">{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/Archives/City-Press/Nazi-report-AfriForum-Youth-threatens-varsity-council-with-Equality-Act-20150429|title=Nazi report: AfriForum Youth threatens varsity council with Equality Act|publisher=City Press}}</ref>
AfriForum continues to drive campaigns to, amongst other things, promote mother tongue education,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.za/2018/01/17/afrikaans-schools-have-a-right-to-be-here-afriforum_a_23335475/|title='Afrikaans Schools Have A Right To Be Here' -- AfriForum|date=2018-01-17|work=HuffPost South Africa|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-ZA}}</ref> keep religion<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/south-africa/2017-06-28-mixed-reaction-to-courts-ruling-against-single-religion-schools/|title=Mixed reaction to court’s ruling against single-religion schools|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref> in schools, and combat detrimental policies and regulations within the schooling system.
The group recently condemned Gauteng MEC for Basic Education [[Panyaza Lesufi]]’s<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://city-press.news24.com/News/youre-defending-your-territory-not-a-language-lesufi-tells-afriforum-20160602|title=You’re defending your territory, not a language, Lesufi tells AfriForum|work=CityPress|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}}</ref> newly proposed school regulations{{clarify|date=September 2018}} and says that the minister continues playing a political game at the expense of learners.{{fact|date=September 2018}} AfriForum further stated that Lesufi was waging a war on Afrikaans schools.{{fact|date=September 2018}}
===Land=== {{see|Land reform in South Africa|South African farm attacks}} The [[South African Institute of Race Relations]] (SAIRR) stated that land is a contentious issue in South Africa, and that the ruling ANC party is blaming whites for still owning 80% of the total land surface. In fact, the Government’s own land-ownership documentation shows that by the start of 2011 roughly 50% of all land was in the hands of Government and black communities.{{Original research inline|date=May 2018}}
As of March 2011, 31 million hectares or 25% of the 122 million hectares surface area of South Africa were in the hands of the State. The remaining 91 million hectares or 75% of the surface area was privately owned. The bulk of white-owned land is probably in the hands of commercial farmers, South Africa's food producers. Their numbers are dwindling rapidly. There are only an estimated 30 000 to 40 000 of these farmers left, down from 60 000 fifteen years ago.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politicsweb.co.za/politicsweb/view/politicsweb/en/page71639?oid=282525&sn=Detail&pid=71639.|title=How much of SA's land is really in black hands? - OPINION - Politicsweb|work=politicsweb.co.za}}</ref>
South African President, [[Jacob Zuma]] called for a review of the land policy, echoing the contents of the Green Paper on Land Reform, but AfriForum claims that the president’s statement regarding the review of willing buyer, willing seller principle as stated in Section 25 of the South African Constitution, as a means to speed up the land restitution process was misplaced.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2012/06/27/afriforum-slams-zuma-land-comments|title=AfriForum slams Zuma land comments|author=Sapa|work=Times LIVE}}</ref> AfriForum has in the past joined the South African Progressive Civic Organisation (Sapco), a Khoisan community, in a protest over the land rights of the indigenous group, with both minority groups feeling they have no representation in the current government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailymaverick.co.za/article/2012-02-22-afriforum-joins-khoisan-in-land-rights-fight|title=AfriForum joins Khoisan in land rights fight|work=dailymaverick.co.za}}</ref>
During 2012, AfriForum's legal team represented the legitimate owners of land in the black community of Wallmansthal, North of Pretoria, in the North Gauteng High Court to take back their land from [[crime|illegal]] [[squatting|squatters]]. The court ruled in favour of AfriForum. The squatters, who occupied the land between December 2011 and February 2012, were removed from the land.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewage.co.za/mobi/Detail.aspx?NewsID=47994&CatID=1009 |title=Eviction order for land invaders given go-ahead |work=thenewage.co.za |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140821041728/http://www.thenewage.co.za/mobi/Detail.aspx?NewsID=47994&CatID=1009 |archivedate=2014-08-21 }}</ref>
During a submission on 6 September 2018 to the Parliamentary Portfolio Committee charged with reviewing Section 25 of the Constitution, AfriForum argued that the ANC/EFF alliance’s{{dubious|date=September 2018}} initiative to carry through expropriation without compensation was nothing but an attempt to centralise as much power as possible in the State, and that the leaders of this policy had no respect for the pleas of poor South Africans.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.politicsweb.co.za/documents/you-are-drunk-on-the-ideology-of-the-ndr--ernst-ro|title=You are drunk on the ideology of the NDR - Ernst Roets - DOCUMENTS {{!}} Politicsweb|website=www.politicsweb.co.za|language=en|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref>{{primary-source-inline|date=September 2018}}
In his submission on behalf of AfriForum, Ernst Roets, Deputy CEO of AfriForum, argued that the campaign of the ANC and its alliance partner, the EFF, was built on a series of false arguments.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/national/2018-09-06-afriforum-bemoans-fallacy-that-whites-stole-the-land/|title=AfriForum bemoans ‘fallacy that whites stole the land’|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref>
AfriForum unleashed a media and public storm when they published a list of farms that are said to be targeted by the government for expropriation without compensation that the organisation received from an anonymous source.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.politicsweb.co.za/documents/this-is-the-list-of-farms-targeted-for-ewc--afrifo|title=This is the list of farms targeted for EWC - AfriForum - DOCUMENTS {{!}} Politicsweb|website=www.politicsweb.co.za|language=en|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref> Although the organisation received a backlash from some organisations and political parties regarding the legitimacy of the list, the South African Institute for Race Relations confirmed and corroborated the legitimacy of the list.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/land-expropriation-list-released-by-afriforum-is-legitimate-irr-20180814|title='Land expropriation list released by AfriForum is legitimate' – IRR|work=News24|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}}</ref>
===Shoot the Boer case and hate speech=== AfriForum Youth opened a civil case against former ANC Youth League President (ANCYL), Julius Malema, in the [[Equality Court]] after his repeated singing of the words “dubul’ ibhunu”, which translate as “shoot the boer”, at a number of ANC Youth League gatherings.<ref name=shtbs>{{cite web|title=ANC youth leader denies hatred in 'Shoot the boer' song|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/apr/20/julius-malema-hate-speech-boer|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> Judge Colin Lamont ruled in the South Gauteng High Court that the song constituted [[hate speech]] and undermined the dignity of Afrikaners, and was discriminatory and harmful.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2011-09-12-shoot-the-boer-its-hate-speech-says-judge|title='Shoot the boer': It's hate speech, says judge|author=Staff Reporter, Sapa-AFP|work=The M&G Online}}</ref><ref name=stbban>{{cite web|title=ANC Julius Malema's Shoot the Boer ruled 'hate speech'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14878102|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref> In 2012, AfriForum and the ANC reached a settlement before the appeal case was due to be argued in the [[Supreme Court of Appeal of South Africa|Supreme Court of Appeal]] (SCA) in [[Bloemfontein]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Shoot-the-Boer-appeal-canned-20121031-2|title=Shoot the Boer appeal canned|work=News24}}</ref>
AfriForum has also brought charges of hate speech against individuals, among others Ronald Lamola, the then acting president of the ANC Youth League following a complaint regarding Lamola's remarks that the ANCYL could no longer guarantee the safety of the Van der Merwes and Van Tonders (traditional white Afrikaans family names) if white South Africans refused to voluntarily give up their land and mineral rights.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.citypress.co.za/politics/hate-speech-charge-laid-against-lamola-20120709-2/ |title=Hate speech charge laid against Lamola |work=News24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121211202232/http://www.citypress.co.za/politics/hate-speech-charge-laid-against-lamola-20120709-2/ |archivedate=2012-12-11 }}</ref> In February 2013 AfriForum Youth brought a complaint of hate speech against Jason Mfusi, the leader of SASCO (The South African Students Congress) of the North-West University for his remark: "My grandfather says 'n goeie boer is 'n dooie boer", translated as “My grandfather says a good farmer is a dead farmer” which he posted on the social network, Facebook. The youth organisation reached an agreement with the SASCO leader by means of a mediation process, as requested by the Human Rights Commission (HRC) of the University. In terms of the agreement, Mfusi had to issue a written apology to the farming community.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sowetanlive.co.za/news/2013/02/07/nwu-student-in-trouble-over-facebook-posting|title=NWU student in trouble over Facebook posting|author=Tebogo Monama|work=Sowetan LIVE}}</ref>
AfriForum adopted a similar stance towards the word [[Kaffir (racial term)|Kaffir]], stating that its use is a "gross human rights violation".<ref name=sabckword>{{cite web|title=AfriForum reaffirm stance on use of K-word amid racist saga|url=http://www.sabc.co.za/news/a/aa9441804fe8018d8628e60b5d39e4bb/AfriForum-reaffirm-stance-on-use-of-K-word-amid-racist-saga|publisher=SABC News|accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref>
===Minority rights=== AfriForum regularly seeks international platforms to speak to the international community regarding the minority rights situation in South Africa. AfriForum has on several occasions attended the [[United Nations]]' [[Human Rights Council]]'s Forum on Minority Issues in [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]] regarding minority rights in South Africa. AfriForum has also been a delegate to a conference of the United Nations’ (UN) Human Rights Council regarding the prevention of the incitement of hatred on the grounds of nationality, race or religion.{{fact|date=May 2018}}
AfriForum has on numerous occasions criticised the ruling ANC about the denial of minority rights in the country.{{fact|date=May 2018}} However, City Press journalist Adriaan Basson (now editor of the Afrikaans daily newspaper, Beeld) has accused the organisation of overreacting to the situation regarding minority rights in South Africa. Basson has mentioned in an open letter to AfriForum CEO, Kallie Kriel, that the premise of AfriForum’s campaigns is one of victimhood.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/Columnists/GuestColumn/White-first-African-second-20110926|title=White first. African second|work=News24}}</ref>

=== Racism === {{Advert|section|date=September 2018}} On 11 September 2018, AfriForum founded a unit against racism and hate speech. Roleplayers who have committed themselves to act as advisors on this unit include: Dr Frans Cronje, CEO of the Institute of Race Relations (IRR), The civil rights activist Rhoda Kadalie, Adv. Mark Oppenheimer, expert in freedom of speech and hate speech and Dr Llewellyn Curlewis, criminal law expert, explained the legal remedies available to citizens to fight racism.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/afriforum-launches-anti-racism-unit-20170911|title=AfriForum launches anti-racism unit|work=News24|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}}</ref>
AfriForum submitted criminal charges against two police officials and a former member of the South African National Defence Force (SANDF) in January 2018 after they used social media to incite farm attacks and/or romanticise violence against farmers and minorities. AfriForum says that these incidents can be considered a form of complicity by the South African government and that it urgently needs to be tackled by the police to ensure that those responsible are prosecuted. Mseleni Mogolwane Gwabeni, who is a member of the SAPS according to his Facebook profile, said on this social media platform “then we must continue to kill more of their farmers at least to make up for what they did to us [sic]”. Chris Gumotso, who works at the SAPS youth crime prevention desk according to his Facebook profile, placed the following on Facebook: “All white man…deserve to die…in future..f*©k u..Mr white man.” He also placed photos of firearms on his police desk on his profile with this quote: “I predict th civil war.. in mzansi…by 2019…take out ur guns…fighters coz Asijiki [sic].”<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.polity.org.za/article/afriforum-lays-criminal-charges-against-police-officials-2018-06-18|title=AfriForum lays criminal charges against police officials|work=Polity.org.za|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref>
In June 2017 AfriForum submitted criminal charges against a 100 social media users for incitement of violence.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://citizen.co.za/news/south-africa/1554475/afriforum-to-lay-charges-against-these-100-social-media-users/|title=AfriForum to lay charges against these 100 social media users|last=reporter|first=Citizen|work=The Citizen|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}}</ref>
AfriForum has been consistent in condemning both white on black and black on white racism. The organisation released media statements in which they address racist incidents involving amongst others Penny Sparrow,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/south-africans-have-double-standards-when-it-comes-to-racism-afriforum-20170216|title=South Africans have double standards when it comes to racism - AfriForum|work=News24|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}}</ref> Darren Scott,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ewn.co.za/2011/09/08/AfriForum-welcomes-Darren-Scotts-apology|title=AfriForum welcomes Darren Scott's apology|last=News|first=Eyewitness|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}}</ref> Dan Roodt,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/AfriForum-condemns-racist-Dan-Roodt-20141113|title=AfriForum condemns 'racist' Dan Roodt|date=2014-11-13|access-date=2018-09-26|work=News24}}</ref> Adam Catzavelos,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2018-08-22-afriforum-condemns-use-of-k-word-by-catzavelos-urges-consistency-in-condemnation-of-racism-from-all-sides/|title=AfriForum condemns use of k-word by Catzavelos‚ urges consistency in condemnation of racism from all sides|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref> and the Kommandokorps.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Kommandokorps-denies-racism-20120227|title=Kommandokorps denies racism|work=News24|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}}</ref> The organisation frequently condemns double standards in South Africa when it comes to dealing with racism.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.politicsweb.co.za/politics/vicki-momberg-sentencing-confirms-double-standards|title=Vicki Momberg: Absurd double standards being applied – AfriForum - POLITICS {{!}} Politicsweb|website=www.politicsweb.co.za|language=en|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref> {{primary-source-inline|date=September 2018}}
==Community affairs==
===Local government=== This department addresses municipal service delivery problems in over 125 towns and cities across South Africa.{{fact|date=May 2018}}
In order to achieve this goal, AfriForum attempts to establish partnerships with municipalities. The organisation allegedly submits wish lists to municipalities, and municipalities convert it into action plans to address issues. AfriForum says if municipalities do not cooperate in improving service delivery to residents, the organisation approaches courts to order municipalities to enforce service delivery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polity.org.za/article/afriforum-statement-by-afriforum-minority-civil-organisation-brings-application-to-retain-electricity-supply-to-klerksdorp-and-jouberton-22022013-2013-02-22|title=AfriForum: Statement by AfriForum, minority civil organisation, brings application to retain electricity supply to Klerksdorp and Jouberton (22/02/2013)|work=Polity.org.za}}</ref> {{Primary source inline|date=May 2018}}
An example of intervention by AfriForum in this regard, was the urgent order awarded to the organisation against the Vhembe District Municipality by the [[High Court]] in [[Pretoria]], forcing the municipality to supply water to [[Makhado]] residents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/crime-courts/afriforum-wins-fights-for-water-1.1394477|title=Afriforum wins fights for water|author=Independent Newspapers Online|work=Independent Online}}</ref> In a similar case in 2013, the North Gauteng High Court in Pretoria granted AfriForum an order stopping the Madibeng Municipality from cutting electricity supply to Hartbeespoort.{{fact|date=May 2018}}
In 2010 a legal team for AfriForum representing farmers in [[Zimbabwe]] won a court bid to sue Zimbabwe's government over its “cruel” and “vengeful” [[expropriation]] of South African-owned farms. In 2008 the regional court SADC tribunal ruled that Zimbabwe's [[land reform]] was illegal and racist, and that those who had suffered discrimination by having their farms expropriated had the right to compensation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/africa/afriforum-wins-first-round-in-zimbabwe-case-1.470355|title=Afriforum wins first round in Zimbabwe case|author=Independent Newspapers Online|work=Independent Online}}</ref>
AfriForum's local government interventions have been described positively, even by its critics.<ref name="news24DuPreez2016Hijacking"/>
===Community safety=== {{Advert section|date=May 2018}} AfriForum’s Community Safety Department participates in endeavours which promote the safety of citizens within communities. A large emphasis is placed on assisting communities and neighbourhoods to establish safety structures. Some of these structures include neighbourhood watches, farm watches, radio networks and community forums.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polity.org.za/article/afriforum-statement-by-reg-crewe-afriforum-head-of-community-safety-vryburg-launches-community-patrols-05112012-2012-11-05|title=AfriForum: Statement by Reg Crewe, Afriforum Head of Community Safety, Vryburg launches community patrols (05/11/2012)|work=Polity.org.za}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=May 2018}}
In 2011 AfriForum commissioned Professor Rudolph Zinn of UNISA to conduct research into successful community safety structures in South Africa. The research has led to the compilation of a community safety handbook that has been implemented in all AfriForum branches countrywide. The department also focuses on the role of government and in particular that of law enforcement agencies, and acts as a pressure group so that citizens get the best safety and security possible.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afriforum.co.za/english/wp-content/uploads/2011/11/report-community-safety-networks.pdf|title=AfriForum|work=AfriForum}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=May 2018}}
==Controversies== In 2015 AfriForum asserted that allegations of racism{{clarify|date=May 2018}} against Curro Foundation School are themselves racist. In a statement by the organisation's chair it was said "To portray an Afrikaans class being transported as class group falsely as racial segregation, is beyond absurd". An investigation into the matter came to the conclusion that the class was in fact segregated racially as was alleged because white parents had pressured the school.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/School-racism-allegations-are-racist-Afriforum-Youth-20150618|title=School racism allegations are 'racist' - Afriforum Youth|publisher=News24}}</ref>
A group of AfriForum protestors were found by judge AJ Donen to have engaged in "assault, sexual violence, sexual aggression and intimidation" at Stellenbosch University,<ref name="news24DuPreez2016Hijacking"/> and the organisation initiated a boycott of Afrikaans newspapers that reported on Potchefstroom students that gave the [[Nazi salute]] during their initiation.<ref name="news24DuPreez2016Hijacking"/>
In 2016 AfriForum supporters protested in Pretoria together with the political party [[Freedom Front Plus]]'s members because Steve Hofmeyr's scheduled event at Café Dudok, a restaurant in the Netherlands, was cancelled when the organisers were alerted of his alleged white supremacy by a left-wing group in Netherlands.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/dailynews/news/hofmeyr-defended-in-dutch-caf-snub-2028898|title=Hofmeyr defended in Dutch café snub|publisher=Daily News}}</ref>
In 2016 eight students affiliated with AfriForum youth wing were suspended from [[Stellenbosch University]] Student Representative Council (SRC) elections after allegations of campaign irregularities. Posters that they produced and hanged around the campus were removed after they were deemed controversial and harmful to other students.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/8-afriforum-students-suspended-from-stellenbosch-src-elections-20160802|title=8 AfriForum students suspended from Stellenbosch SRC elections|publisher=News24}}</ref>
In May 2018, following criticism of Afriforum by a [[North-West University]] professor, Elmien du Plessis,<ref name="afriforumStatsDuPlessis">{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/Columnists/GuestColumn/afriforums-own-farm-murder-stats-dont-support-their-claims-20180507|title=AfriForum's own farm murder stats don't support their claims|publisher=News24}}</ref> Afriforum's deputy CEO, Ernst Roets, posted a YouTube video where he quoted [[Victor Klemperer]], stating that "if the tables were turned after the Holocaust he "would have all the intellectuals strung up, and the professors three feet higher than the rest; they would be left hanging from the lamp posts for as long as was compatible with hygiene."<ref name="huffPoHevyWeightAttack">{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.za/2018/05/06/afriforum-heavyweight-launches-attack-on-academic-over-criticism-about-us-tour_a_23428355/|title=AfriForum Heavyweight Launches Attack On Academic Over Criticism About US Tour|date=6 May 2018|publisher=Huffington Post South Africa}}</ref> Following the video posting, du Plessis and her family received threats of violence.<ref name="huffPoProfThreatened">{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.za/2018/05/07/professor-threatened-after-afriforum-criticism-dont-get-too-comfortable-youre-next_a_23429098/|title=Professor Threatened After AfriForum Criticism: 'Don't Get Too Comfortable, You're Next'|date=8 May 2018|publisher= Huffington Post South Africa}}</ref><ref name="news24ThreatsViolenceHanging">{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/varsity-prof-on-afriforums-angry-roets-threat-of-violence-hanging-not-acceptable-20180507|title=Varsity prof on AfriForum's 'angry' Roets: 'Threat of violence, hanging not acceptable'|publisher=News24}}</ref><ref name="habibHitsOutAfriforum">{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/p2-academic-adam-habib-hits-out-at-disgusting-afriforum-leaders-20180510|title=Academic Adam Habib hits out at 'disgusting' AfriForum leaders|publisher=}}</ref> A petition condemning the threats against academics was subsequently circulated.<ref name="huffPocademicPetitionCirculated">{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.za/2018/05/14/petition-against-afriforum-over-threat-to-academics_a_23434037/|title=Petition Against AfriForum Over Threat To Academics|date=14 May 2018|publisher=Huffington Post South Africa}}</ref>
AfriForum CEO Kallie Kriel attracted widespread controversy in May 2018 when he denied that [[Apartheid]] was a [[Crime of apartheid|crime against humanity]],<ref name="mgMay2018KrielApartheidCrime">{{cite web|url=https://mg.co.za/article/2018-05-14-i-dont-think-apartheid-was-a-crime-against-humanity-afriforums-kallie-kriel|title=I don't think apartheid was a crime against humanity – Afriforum’s Kriel|first=Mashadi|last=Kekana|publisher=Mail and Guardian}}</ref><ref name="citizenKrielApartheidCrime">{{cite web|url=https://citizen.co.za/news/news-cns/1926171/apartheid-was-not-a-crime-afriforum/|title=Apartheid was not a crime – AfriForum|first=Robinson|last=Nqola|publisher=The Citizen}}</ref><ref name="702ApartheidCrimeKriel">{{cite web|url=http://www.702.co.za/articles/303461/i-dont-think-apartheid-was-a-crime-against-humanity-kriel|title=AfriForum's Kallie Kriel: I don't think apartheid was a crime against humanity|website=702}}</ref><ref name="news24ApartheidCrimeKriel">{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/apartheid-was-not-a-crime-against-humanity-afriforum-ceo-20180514|title=Apartheid was not a crime against humanity - AfriForum CEO|publisher=News24}}</ref><ref name="iolKrielCrimeHumanity">{{cite web|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/apartheid-no-crime-against-humanity-says-afriforums-kriel-14973712|title=Apartheid no crime against humanity, says AfriForum's Kriel|publisher=IOL News}}</ref><ref name ="timesLiveUproarApartheid">{{cite web|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2018-05-15-uproar-over-remark-that-apartheid-was-not-a-crime-against-humanity-by-afriforum-ceo/|title='Apartheid was not a crime against humanity': AfriForum CEO's remark sparks outrage|publisher=Times Live}}</ref><ref name="timesLiveWhoIsKriel">{{cite web|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2018-05-15-who-is-afriforum-ceo-kallie-kriel/|title=Who is AfriForum CEO Kallie Kriel?|publisher=Times Live}}</ref><ref name="iolKrielTryingToRevise">{{cite web|url=https://www.iol.co.za/pretoria-news/kriel-trying-to-revise-history-14998001|title='Kriel trying to revise history'|publisher=Pretoria News}}</ref> and its deputy leader Ernst Roets has described Apartheid as a "wooly concept".<ref name="huffPoParallelState"/> The organisation had previously described Apartheid as a "so-called historical injustice".<ref name="huffPoFerialMorake">{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.za/ferial-haffajee/ferial-haffajee-tumi-morake-solidarity-and-21st-century-baasskap_a_23216514/|title=Ferial Haffajee: Tumi Morake, Solidarity And 21st Century Baasskap|date=20 September 2017|publisher=Huffington Post}}</ref><ref name="news24DuPreez2016Hijacking"/><ref name="sowetanApartheidCrimeHumanity"/><ref name="businessDayApartheidCrime">{{cite web|url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/national/2018-05-15-apartheid-not-a-crime-against-humanity--says-afriforum-ceo-kallie-kriel/|title=Apartheid not a crime against humanity, says AfriForum CEO Kallie Kriel|publisher=Business Day}}</ref>
==Criticism== The organisation has been criticized, most notability by the ruling ANC as well as by media outlets such as City Press, including the paper’s editor Ferial Haffajee<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.citypress.co.za/Columnists/Laager-mentality-is-a-load-of-bull-20101002/ |title=Laager mentality is a load of bull |work=News24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121119232400/http://www.citypress.co.za/Columnists/Laager-mentality-is-a-load-of-bull-20101002 |archivedate=2012-11-19 }}</ref> and academics such as University of Cape Town Professor Pierre de Vos.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://constitutionallyspeaking.co.za/how-not-to-engage-in-a-battle-of-ideas/|title=How not to engage in a battle of ideas|work=constitutionallyspeaking.co.za}}</ref> Survivalist groups such as the Kommandokorps have also criticised the organisation, alleging that the group is too moderate in their approach to problems facing South Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Kommandokorps-denies-racism-20120227|title=Kommandokorps denies racism|work=News24}}</ref>
A [[Chapter 9 institution]], the [[Commission for the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Cultural, Religious and Linguistic Communities]], launched an attack on AfriForum's campaign for the protection of [[Afrikaans]] medium schools in a press release.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.info.gov.za/speech/DynamicAction?pageid=461&sid=24488&tid=53893 |title=Redirecting old link |work=info.gov.za }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> It was presumed by AfriForum that the Commission deliberately acted in contravention of its mandate as set out in Section 185 of the Constitution, which led AfriForum to suspect that the Commission was functioning as an extension of the ruling party.{{fact|date=May 2018}}
The [[African National Congress Youth League]] has stated that AfriForum is "the defender of white privilege"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/afriforum-defender-of-white-priviledge-ancyl-1.1313072|title=Afriforum ‘defender of white privilege’: ANCYL|author=Independent Newspapers Online|work=Independent Online}}</ref> while commentator and journalist [[Max du Preez]] has described AfriForum's position as "reactionary identity politics", and claimed that Afrikaners who criticised AfriForum are "aggressively demonised, insulted, belittled and even threatened".<ref name="duPreezAfriForumDaProblem">{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/Columnists/MaxduPreez/the-problem-afriforum-is-causing-the-da-20180515|title=The problem AfriForum is causing the DA|publisher=News24}}</ref>
Vice Chancellor of the [[University of the Witwatersrand]] [[Adam Habib]] condemned AfriForum in May 2018 and said in an interview that the AfriForum was building ties with "[[proto-fascist]] groups" including the French [[National Front (France)|National Front]], the Italian [[Five Star Movement]], and Germany's [[Alternative for Germany|AFD]].<ref name="iolKrielTryingToRevise"/>

[[File:Artamus cyanopterus Mortimer.jpg|thumb|[[Dusky woodswallow]] (''Artamus cyanopterus'') parent feeding a [[wasp]] to chicks]]
'''Allofeeding''' is a type of [[Evolutionary models of food sharing|food sharing]] [[Behavior|behaviour]] observed in [[Cooperative breeding|cooperatively breed]]ing species of [[bird]]s. Allofeeding refers to a parent, sibling or unrelated adult bird feeding [[altricial]] [[hatchling]]s, which are dependent on [[parental care]] for their survival.<ref name="barrows">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=yaXMBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA13&dq=evolution+of+allofeeding&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjE9ePx_sHRAhWLq1QKHUJ1CC8Q6AEINjAF#v=onepage&q=evolution%20of%20allofeeding&f=false|title=Animal Behavior Desk Reference|last=Barrows|first=Edward M.|publisher=CRC Press|year=2011|isbn=978-1-4398-3652-1|edition=3rd|location=Boca Raton, FL}}</ref> Allofeeding also refers to food sharing between adults of the same species.<ref name="handicap">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=ImjqhNqjiqsC&pg=PA137&dq=evolution+of+allofeeding&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi-jfi2gMLRAhVIhlQKHVOQAHE4ChDoAQgfMAE#v=onepage&q=evolution%20of%20allofeeding&f=false|title=The Handicap Principle: A Missing Piece of Darwin's Puzzle|last1=Zahavi|first1=Amotz|last2=Zahavi|first2=Avishag|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=1997|isbn=0-19-510035-2}}</ref> Allofeeding can occur between mates during mating rituals, [[Courtship display|courtship]], egg laying or incubation, between peers of the same species, or as a form of parental care.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Smith|first=Susan M.|date=1980|title=Demand Behavior: A New Interpretation of Courtship Feeding|jstor=1367395|journal=The Condor|volume=82|issue=3|pages=291–295|doi=10.2307/1367395}}</ref><ref name=":33">{{Cite journal|last=Halley|first=Matthew R.|last2=Holmes|first2=Aaron L.|last3=Robinson|first3=W. Douglas|date=2015-06-01|title=Biparental incubation and allofeeding at nests of Sagebrush Brewer's Sparrows|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jofo.12098/abstract|journal=Journal of Field Ornithology|language=en|volume=86|issue=2|pages=153–162|doi=10.1111/jofo.12098|issn=1557-9263}}</ref>
Allofeeding evolved for different reasons in different species of birds. While Sagebrush Brewer’s Sparrows allofeed to reduce [[predation]] during incubation, Sichuan Jays allofeed to increase a female’s nutritional level prior to egg laying, and Chinstrap Penguins allofeed to strengthen the bond between the pair during chick guarding.<ref name=":33" /><ref name=":44">{{Cite journal|last=Jing|first=Yu|last2=Fang|first2=Yun|last3=Strickland|first3=Dan|last4=Lu|first4=Nan|last5=Sun|first5=Yue-Hua|date=2009|title=Alloparenting in the Rare Sichuan Jay (Perisoreus Internigrans) - Cuidado Aloparental en la Especie Rara Perisoreus internigrans|journal=The Condor|volume=111|issue=4|pages=662–667|doi=10.1525/cond.2009.080114|jstor=10.1525/cond.2009.080114}}</ref><ref name=":54">{{Cite journal|last=Mori|first=Yoshihisa|last2=Kokubun|first2=Nobuo|last3=Shin|first3=Hyoung-Chul|last4=Takahashi|first4=Akinori|date=2010-10-01|title=An observation of between-mates feeding behaviour in chick-guarding chinstrap penguins|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00300-010-0842-8|journal=Polar Biology|language=en|volume=33|issue=10|pages=1437–1438|doi=10.1007/s00300-010-0842-8|issn=0722-4060}}</ref>
While parental allofeeding is a common form of parental care among many species of birds, the practice is not inherently restricted to biological parents and their young, and is often done for reasons unrelated to the well-being of the chicks. Arabian Bablers, for instance, peer allofeed in an attempt at increasing their social rank, whereas the King Penguin considers those 'non-breeders' who allofeed chicks to be altruistic and highly revered. And the far more practical Barn Owl, of course, peer allofeeds merely to reduce sibling rivalry/competition during meal times.<ref name=":03">{{Cite journal|last=Carlisle|first=Tamsie R.|last2=Zahavi|first2=Amotz|date=1986-04-01|title=Helping at the nest, allofeeding and social status in immature arabian babblers|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00299665|journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology|language=en|volume=18|issue=5|pages=339–351|doi=10.1007/BF00299665|issn=0340-5443}}</ref><ref name=":63">{{Cite journal|last=Roulin|first=A.|last2=Monstiers|first2=B. Des|last3=Ifrid|first3=E.|last4=Silva|first4=A. Da|last5=Genzoni|first5=E.|last6=Dreiss|first6=A. N.|date=2016-02-01|title=Reciprocal preening and food sharing in colour-polymorphic nestling barn owls|url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1111/jeb.12793|journal=Journal of Evolutionary Biology|language=en|volume=29|issue=2|pages=380–394|doi=10.1111/jeb.12793|issn=1420-9101}}</ref>
Although many species of birds exhibit allofeeding, there are some species that do not perform allofeeding, such as Siberian Jays.<ref name=":44" />
== Allofeeding between mates == Many species of migratory [[songbird]]s display allofeeding during the [[incubation period]].<ref name=":33" /> During the incubation period, a male songbird will feed its mate, while she sits on the eggs through beak-to-beak interaction.<ref name=":33" /> This allofeeding behaviour is suggested to be adaptive because the male is indirectly investing in its offspring.<ref name=":33" /> The male uses its energy to forage and retrieve food, and to feed the female.<ref name=":33" /> This behaviour of the male reduces nutritional stress of the female because it reduces the amount of time the female spends foraging.<ref name=":33" /> In addition, the allofeeding behaviour decreases the number of times a female has to leave the nest, which in turn extends the incubation period and reduces the risk of nest being detected by a predator.<ref name=":33" /> Overall, allofeeding behaviour contributes to increased fitness and is therefore considered advantageous.<ref name=":33" /> However, Nolan (1958) theorizes that allofeeding is a non-adaptive and is derived from anticipatory parental care.<ref name=":33" />
Allofeeding during the incubation period can also transpire through both the male and the female interchangeably feeding each other via beak-to-beak interactions, while a mate receiving the food incubates the eggs.<ref name=":33" /> Once feeding is completed, the recipient now becomes the feeder and the mate that was just foraging incubates the eggs. For example, Sagebrush Brewer’s Sparrows (''Spizella breweri breweri'') allofeed in this manner.<ref name=":33" /> A recent study by Halley et al., 2015, examined allofeeding in twenty-four nests of Sagebrush Brewer’s Sparrows.<ref name=":33" /> This study revealed that allofeeding occurred at low frequencies (55%) in nests with biparental incubation and no allofeeding occurred in uniparental nests.<ref name=":33" /> This study suggests that allofeeding is an intraspecific signal required to maintain social bonds between mates, in addition to increasing the nutrition levels of females and concealment of the nest.<ref name=":33" /> Furthermore, the study found that incubation sessions per hour were higher in biparental nests with allofeeding than in biparental nests without allofeeding.<ref name=":33" /> These findings indicate that allofeeding is beneficial because it reduces the risk of predation from visually oriented predators through increased nest concealment,<ref name=":33" /> which can maximize the fitness of males while increasing the fitness of females.<ref name=":33" />
There have been many documented observations of allofeeding between mates (mate allofeeding).<ref name=":54" /> However, in penguins allofeeding between mates is rare.<ref name=":54" /> In 2010, [[Chinstrap penguin|Chinstrap Penguins]] (''P. antarctica'') allofeeding was reported during the period of chick guarding.<ref name=":54" /> The researchers witnessed a male feeding a female, which had a large chick in its nest.<ref name=":54" /> The behaviour was engaged by the female frequently pecking the side of the male’s bill to stimulate the male to regurgitate its food.<ref name=":54" /> This resulted in the male regurgitating its food into the female’s open mouth. This allofeeding behaviour was identical to the manner in which a chick begs its parent for food.<ref name=":54" /> Notably, during this behaviour the female kept the attention of male when the chick tried to gain the male’s attention.<ref name=":54" /> It is proposed that mate allofeeding in Chinstrap Penguins was performed to strengthen the bond between the pair.<ref name=":54" />
Allofeeding between mates can also occur during courtship.<ref name=":54" /> Courtship allofeeding occurs in half of bird subfamilies and mainly appears in monogamous bird species.<ref name=":54" /> Courtship allofeeding is hypothesized to strengthen the bond between pairs or increase a female’s nutritional level before laying eggs.<ref name=":54" /> For example, in the Sichuan Jay ([[Sichuan jay|''P. internigrans'']]), females are fed by only one male during courtship.<ref name=":44" /> It is suggested that allofeeding the female during courtship, increases a female’s nutritional level before egg laying.<ref name=":44" /> This behaviour was also recorded in the Grey Jays (''[[Grey jay|P. canadensis]]'').<ref name=":44" /> Other species of birds display allofeeding during courtship. Additionally, courtship allofeeding in some birds species is hypothesized to strengthen the bond between pairs.<ref name=":54" />
== Allofeeding and parental care ==
=== ''Aptenodytes patagonicus'' === [[File:Emperor-feeding_hg.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Emperor-feeding_hg.jpg|thumb|Emperor Penguin (''Aptenodytes patagonicus)'' feeding its offspring]] A parent feeding a non-biological chick via bill-to-bill interactions is a form of allofeeding.<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Lecomte|first=Nicolas|last2=Kuntz|first2=Gregoire|last3=Lambert|first3=Nicolas|last4=Gendner|first4=Jean-Paul|last5=Handrich|first5=Yves|last6=Maho|first6=Yvon Le|last7=Bost|first7=Charles-André|title=Alloparental feeding in the king penguin|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0003347205004173|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=71|issue=2|pages=457–462|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2005.07.007}}</ref><ref name=":23">{{Cite journal|last=Jouventin|first=Pierre|last2=Barbraud|first2=Christophe|last3=Rubin|first3=Michel|title=Adoption in the emperor penguin, Aptenodytes forsteri|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/0003-3472(95)80102-2|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=50|issue=4|pages=1023–1029|doi=10.1016/0003-3472(95)80102-2}}</ref> Parental allofeeding occurs in all altricial species of birds to ensure proper growth, development, and to prevent starvation of their offspring.<ref name=":113">{{Cite journal|last=Eggers|first=Sönke|last2=Griesser|first2=Michael|last3=Ekman|first3=Jan|date=2005-01-01|title=Predator-induced plasticity in nest visitation rates in the Siberian jay (Perisoreus infaustus)|url=http://academic.oup.com/beheco/article/16/1/309/206728/Predatorinduced-plasticity-in-nest-visitation|journal=Behavioral Ecology|language=en|volume=16|issue=1|pages=309–315|doi=10.1093/beheco/arh163|issn=1045-2249}}</ref> This form of allofeeding has been shown to be a form of parental care in some species, such as in King Penguins ([[King penguin|''A. patagonicus'']]).<ref name=":13" /> King Penguins are pelagic seabirds.<ref name=":13" /> King Penguin chicks form dense groups called crèches during winter for social thermoregulation when food availability is low.<ref name=":13" /><ref name=":23" /> The formation of crèches results from the parents interchangeably leaving starving chicks to gather food from the sea.<ref name=":13" /><ref name=":23" /> A study by Lecomte et al., 2015 examined the allofeeding behaviour in King Penguins, in which they marked the white underbellies of 74 non-breeding adults and 103 breeding pairs with a unique dark colouring called dye-mark code of Nyanzol-D.<ref name=":13" /> Lecomte et al. (2015) found 22% of the marked adults feed 65% of the chicks in crèches, revealing that allofeeding behaviour was most common during the breeding season.<ref name=":13" /> Lecomte et al. (2015) also identified that most of the 22% of adult King Penguins demonstrating allofeeding behaviour were unable to successfully breed along with few breeders performing the behaviour.<ref name=":13" /> The allofeeding behaviour resulted in more feedings for chicks,<ref name=":13" /> which is consistent with study by Pierre et al. (1994) that showed that allofeeding in penguins increases the chick growth rate from 35g/day to 190g/day.<ref name=":23" /> From these results, Lecomte et al., (2015) concluded that allofeeding increased the survival rate of chicks in crèches.<ref name=":13" /><ref name=":23" /> The results imply that parental allofeeding in King Penguins is an altruistic behaviour, where allofeeding benefits the young at a cost to the non-biological parent.<ref name=":13" /> Notably, no direct benefits to the non-biological parents have been described.<ref name=":13" /> The cost of allofeeding non-biological chicks resulted in no detrimental effects to the fitness of the [[Alloparenting|alloparent]], because the cost of allofeeding is low (several grams) when compared to the nutritional costs of an adult king penguin, which is several kilograms.<ref name=":13" /> However, it is suggested that allofeeding many chicks may cost each chick lost meals that can cause negative effects on the fitness of allofed chicks.<ref name=":13" /> In addition, allofeeding decreases when non-biological parents had offspring.<ref name=":13" />
=== ''Pseudomonas antarctica'' === The [[Chinstrap penguin|Chinstrap Penguin]] (''P. antarctica'') is another species of penguin that displays allofeeding.<ref name=":54" /> Allofeeding in the Chinstrap Penguin has been observed between the female and its offspring.<ref name=":54" /> Similar to mate allofeeding in this species, the offspring of a female will peck the side of the female’s bill to signal the female to regurgitate its food into the chick's open mouth.<ref name=":54" />
=== ''Perisoreus internigrans'' === In Sichuan Jays ([[Sichuan jay|''P. Internigrans'']]), females are not the only sex that participates in the allofeeding of their offspring.<ref name=":44" /> During their first week of life, the chicks are only fed by the male.<ref name=":73">{{Cite news|url=https://britishbirds.co.uk/article/studies-of-less-familiar-birds-162-siberian-jay/|title=Studies of less Familiar birds 162 Siberian Jay - British Birds|last=Blomgren|first=Arne Blomgren|date=|work=British Birds|access-date=2018-03-12|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref> The male forages and stores food in a pouch within its throat. At the nest, the male regurgitates the semi-digested food from its pouch into the mouths of its chicks.<ref name=":73" /> After the first week, the male continues to feed the chicks while the female begins feeding the chicks.<ref name=":44" /> The female uses the same method as the male.<ref name=":73" />
== Peer allofeeding ==
=== ''Turdoides sqamiceps'' === There have been many reported cases of allofeeding between siblings in several species of birds.<ref name=":03" /> For example, the Arabian Babblers ([[Arabian babbler|''T. sqamiceps'']]) are a territorial, desert inhibiting species of bird that participate in cooperative breeding.<ref name=":03" /> In this species, non-breeders show numerous types of cooperative behaviour, including allofeeding.<ref name=":03" /> Adult and immature Babblers, as well as previous and newly fledged Babblers, will frequently engage in allofeeding behaviour.<ref name=":03" />
Carlisle et al. (1986) revealed that Arabian Babblers participate in peer allofeeding in order to increase social rank, which increases fitness.<ref name=":03" /> This allofeeding behaviour is supported by the Zahavi's hypothesis.<ref name=":03" /> An individual (a dominate Babbler) can increase in social rank by allofed a subordinate Babbler.<ref name=":03" /> On the contrary, an individual (a subordinate Babbler) can decrease in social rank when they are allofed by a dominate Babbler.<ref name=":03" /> Subordinate Babblers have been observed refusing to be allofeed by dominate Babbler.<ref name=":03" /> The refusal resulted in the dominate Babbler becoming aggressive with the subordinate - hitting or chasing the subordinate.<ref name=":03" /> Dominate Babblers also showed the same aggressive behaviours when a subordinate tried to allofeed it.<ref name=":03" />
=== ''Tyto alba'' === Another species that exhibits peer allofeeding is the [[Barn owl|Barn Owl]] (''T. alba'').<ref name=":63" /> Barn Owl nest siblings establish a hierarchy for the sharing of food resources via vocal negotiations.<ref name=":63" /> It is suggested that Barn Owl nest siblings show peer allofeeding to reduce sibling competition in the food sharing hierarchy.<ref name=":63" /> Peer allofeeding observed in 60 nestling pairs revealed that the behaviour occurs by a donor sibling placing the food item on the ground in front of the receiver sibling, which transfers the food item to its bill using its talons.<ref name=":63" /> Alternatively, the donor sibling uses its bill to place the food item in the bill of the receiver sibling.<ref name=":63" /> As well, peer allofeeding behaviour in Barn Owl siblings is proposed to increase the [[inclusive fitness]] of the peer performing the allofeeding.<ref name=":63" />
== Intraspecific allofeeding ==
=== ''Perisoreus Internigrans'' === [[File:Perisoreus_canadensis_feeding_at_nest.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Perisoreus_canadensis_feeding_at_nest.jpg|thumb|Gray Jays (''Perisoreus canadensis)'' feeding offspring at the nest]] Intraspecific allofeeding in Sichuan Jays (''[[Sichuan jay|P. internigrans]]'') is performed during the nestling and fledging period by non-breeders.<ref name=":44" /> One to three non-breeders support a nesting breeding pair by feeding the chicks, regurgitating the food from their throat pouches.<ref name=":44" /><ref name=":73" /> In 2009, Jing et al. determined that two non-breeders contributed to 44% of feedings in the nest of two Sichuan Jays.<ref name=":44" /> Jing et al. (2009) suggest that allofeeding behaviour contributes to increased nest survival.<ref name=":44" />
In Sichuan Jays, allofeeding is hypothesized to be evolutionary selected.<ref name=":44" /> In this species, two to three non-breeders will allofeed the young of a breeding pair.<ref name=":44" /> The large body mass (21% heavier than Siberian Jays) of the Sichuan Jays, and the presence of more than one non-breeder, allows one non-breeder to ward off a predator while another non-breeder protects the young from additional predators.<ref name=":44" /> Both the large body mass of the non-breeders and the presence of multiple non-breeders reduces the risk of injury or death when predators are encountered.<ref name=":44" /> This reveals that the benefits of allofeeding the young outweighs the cost of injury or death of the non-breeder and/or chick when more than one non-breeder is present.<ref name=":44" /> Peer allofeeding has also been observed in the Gray Jay (''[[Grey jay|P. canadensis]]'').<ref name=":44" /> In the Gray Jay, non-breeders allofeed the young after fledging.<ref name=":44" />
Not all species of jays allofeed their young, such as the Siberian Jay (''[[Siberian jay|P. infaustus]]'').<ref name=":44" /> In the Siberian Jays, non-breeders do not allofeed the chicks of a breeding pair.<ref name=":44" /> It is predicted that Siberian Jays do not display allofeeding because the cost of predation is too high.<ref name=":44" /> Siberian Jays are continuously threatened by a more dangerous predators, the Eurasian Sparrowhawk and Northern Goshawk, then Gray Jays, which are threatened by Eurasian red squirrel.<ref name=":44" /> One non-breeder per breeding pair and the small size (21% less body mass than the Sichuan Jays) of the Siberian Jays, in combination with continuous risk of predation, reveals that the non-breeding Siberian Jays are unable to confront predators and protect the nest simultaneously.<ref name=":44" /> This indicates that the cost of allofeeding the young is more costly to the non-breeder when one non-breeder is present because an encounter with a predator increases the risk of injury and death of both the young and the non-breeder.<ref name=":44" /> This reveals that the benefit of allofeeding the young does not exceed the cost of injury or death of non-breeder and/or young.<ref name=":44" /> This is consistent with the predator-avoidance hypothesis, suggesting that the cost of allofeeding in the Siberian Jays prevents allofeeding from being evolutionary selected.<ref name=":44" />

A [[bounded sequence|bounded]] [[real number|real]] [[sequence]] <math>(x_n)</math> is said to be ''almost convergent'' to <math>L</math> if each [[Banach limit]] assigns the same value <math>L</math> to the sequence <math>(x_n)</math>.
Lorentz proved that <math>(x_n)</math> is almost convergent if and only if :<math>\lim\limits_{p\to\infty} \frac{x_{n}+\ldots+x_{n+p-1}}p=L</math> uniformly in <math>n</math>.
The above limit can be rewritten in detail as :<math>\forall \varepsilon>0 : \exists p_0 : \forall p>p_0 : \forall n : \left|\frac{x_{n}+\ldots+x_{n+p-1}}p-L\right|<\varepsilon.</math> Almost convergence is studied in [[summability theory]]. It is an example of a summability method which cannot be represented as a matrix method.<ref>Hardy,p.52</ref>
==References== * G. Bennett and [[Nigel Kalton|N.J. Kalton]]: "Consistency theorems for almost convergence." Trans. Amer. Math. Soc., 198:23--43, 1974. * J. Boos: "Classical and modern methods in summability." Oxford University Press, New York, 2000. * J. Connor and K.-G. Grosse-Erdmann: "Sequential definitions of continuity for real functions." Rocky Mt. J. Math., 33(1):93--121, 2003. * G.G. Lorentz: "A contribution to the theory of divergent sequences." Acta Math., 80:167--190, 1948. * {{citation|title=Divergent Series|first=G. H.|last=Hardy|authorlink=G. H. Hardy|publication-place=Oxford|publisher=Clarendon Press|year=1949|url=https://archive.org/details/divergentseries033523mbp}}.
